awd_titl_txt: NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship in Biology FY 2021: A Novel Model System for Studying the Evolution and Genomics of Longevity
awd_abstract_narration:
This action funds an NSF Postdoctoral Research Fellowship in Biology for FY 2021, Broadening Participation of Groups Under-represented in Biology. The Fellowship supports a research and training plan for the Fellow that will increase the participation of groups underrepresented in biology. Lifespan is one of the most diverse traits across the tree of life. Work in model organisms demonstrates a strong role of genetics in determining an organism’s maximum lifespan. However, the full extent to which genes, environment, and life histories interact to influence the lifespan of particularly long-lived animals is still uncertain. Bats provide the perfect system to study the genetics of lifespan and the evolution of exceptional longevity. This project will establish a comprehensive system for studying the evolution and genetics of lifespan in bats at multiple levels of biology. Moreover, the methodology and resources will benefit all bat biologists by allowing researchers to comprehensively study other traits, such as the evolution of disease tolerance, and the genetic adaptations to their environments. This research also adds to the long list of reasons why bats are vital to the environment and provides a novel angle for people to become interested in both evolution and ecology as tools to address both new and old questions. This project will also broaden participation in biology by bringing in students from underrepresented and disadvantaged backgrounds, as well as by providing a wealth of educational experiences for the public via a new and exciting view into how evolution be used as a tool to understand the modern world.

The project focuses on 9 species of bats (genus Myotis) in the western United States and involves generating primary cell lines from wing-punch biopsies of multiple individuals in order to create three new resources: 1) a chromosome-level reference genome per species; 2) phased population genetic data for each species; and 3) cell line biobanks for in vitro functional experiments. By analyzing the high-quality genomes for each species alongside the population genetic data, the fellow will determine which genetic changes – both ancient and recent – are associated with the evolution of longevity in bats which are either longer- or short-lived than their ancestors. These hypotheses will then be validated using the primary cell lines from each species, enabling a comprehensive study into the evolution of longevity and longevity-associated traits.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this project was to develop the tools and resources necessary to study the evolution of longevity and longevity-associated traits in long-lived bats using cutting-edge genomics tools. This involved gathering samples over 450 hours of work in the field; the generation of cell lines from collected samples; the collection of high-molecular weight DNA for sequencing; assembling sequenced DNA into chromosome-scale genomes; annotating these genomes to identify all protein-coding genes; and aligning these genes to orthologous genes from other published genomes.

With these genes, we were able to redefine the phylogeny that describes how these species are related to one another, and look for genes associated with extraordinary longevity in bats. Our results highlight how exceptional bats are in general, and how their biology has shaped their extraordinary lifespan in specific. 

In addition to the reference genomes we generated, we also collected tissue samples from nearly 300 individuals across our 9 bat species of interest from locations spread across the Southwest (CA, AZ, and NV). By extracting DNA from these samples and sending it out for sequencing, we are now able to generate population genetic data for bats in these regions; this will allow us to understand how differences in their local environmental history have shaped their genetics, which can inform us about not only how long they may live, but also on how they will be able to adapt to new environmental changes and challenges. 

In order to test the theories and genes we identify using comparative genetics, we have also generated a collection of over 230 cell lines across 33 species of bats. This resource has allowed us to assess how bats respond to DNA damage and other stressors, such as oxidative stress and heat shock, without needing to subject the bats to any additional harm. This also allows us to control for the effects of the environment on our study by providing a uniform context for all of our experiments. In the future, these cell lines will be invaluable for performing direct tests of gene function in the genes we have identified through other methods. 

Overall, our work here provides a foundation for not just the future of aging research in bats, but for the future of bat research across a variety of disciplines, including conservation, ecology and evolution, and diease ecology. Our work also provides a blueprint for replicating these tools in other systems of interest, including whales and other extraordinarily long-lived species, to improve our ability to address fundamental questions in the evolution of longevity.
